ygData.subject: News and Developments
ygData.msgSnippet: Hey everyone, I wanted to post a quick message about what I ve been up to recently. As some of you know, I started as an assistant professor at UCF 6 months

Hey everyone, I wanted to post a quick message about what I've been 
up to =
recently.  

As some of you know, I started as an assistant professor at UC=
F 6 
months ago.  As you'd expect, being a new professor is very time 
cons=
uming, which has kept me from posting as much as I'd like to in 
this group=
.  In any case, I did manage to start a research group, 
which is called "E=
Plex," which is short for the Evolutionary 
Complexity Research Group at UC=
F.  You may find it interesting to 
browse our (very new) site:

http://epl=
ex.cs.ucf.edu/

This group is about what it says: how to evolve high-level =

complexity with computers.  Evolutionary computation has so far 
failed to=
 accomplish this feat, even as nature has clearly 
succeeded.  Thus there i=
s some break in the analogy between the two, 
and we are aiming to bridge t=
hat gap.  Not surprisingly, I think the 
NEAT method is part of the puzzle,=
 though clearly not the whole 
thing.  Indirect encoding is another big par=
t.

We do have a single publication, which is a tech report I just 
recentl=
y put up.  (A shorter symposium version will also be up 
shortly):

http://=
eplex.cs.ucf.edu/index.php?
option=3Dcom_content&task=3Dview&id=3D14&Itemid=
=3D28#stanley.ucftr0601

(It's also available from the publications section=
 of the EPlex site)

You'll see from the report and the site that I got a l=
ot of new 
ideas about indirect encoding from playing with NEAT-based Genet=
ic 
Art programs! (thanks to Mattias and Holger for writing those 
programs=
)  Anyway, you can read the paper for more.  I'm happy to 
discuss it :)

k=
en
